On Wed, 12 May 2004, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> Glenn Robitaille wrote:
>
> > As we all know, Java doesn't support multiple inheritance.  You can
> > only extend TestCase or you business class, but not both.  If you
> > want to use JUnit with a derived class, it seems you have to
> > implement a lot of methods from the TestCase interface -- which
> > isn't practical.
> ...
> Put simply, what you propose to do goes entirely against JUnit's
> philosophy, as well as the more general testing philosophies of the
> xUnit family of testing frameworks. Tests are tests and production code
> is production code.

Interestingly enough, in the engineering world, having testing stuff
built into the final product is very common. In part this is due to the
vagaries of manufacturing, of course; you want some way to ascertain
that this particular CPU you built functions as it should, which is not
normally a problem with software where you can produce perfect replicas.

However, now that I've played around with Ruby a bit, I am rather
getting to like the idea of getting the test and production code
"closer together." I often put my test classes in the same file as the
production code, which can save a lot of switching back and forth. You
can even define a but of the production class, a bit of the test class
with the tests for that method or whatever, a bit more of the production
class, and so on.

> Why do you want a production class also to be a test? I think it's
> generally a very bad idea.

I don't see what the problem with it is. It might cause a bit of code
bloat, but that's often not a problem in many projects.

> This brings up something I am struggling with: in C#/NUnit, we can
> declare a test without extending TestCase (even if we frequently extend
> Assert, anyway). Is there some great benefit to this over the way we do
> it in JUnit, SUnit, RubyUnit, PyUnit, ...?

You can do the same in Ruby's Test::Unit:

    require 'test/unit/testsuite'
    require 'test/unit/ui/console/testrunner'

    class NonTestcaseTest
	def size; 1; end
	def run(result); result.add_run; end
    end

    suite = Test::Unit::TestSuite.new
    suite << NonTestcaseTest.new
    Test::Unit::UI::Console::TestRunner.run(suite)

In Ruby, and it sounds like in C#, "interfaces" are defined by what
messages an object will respond to; there's no need to explicitly
declare them. Java people tend to be pretty uncomfortable with this, but
it's a basic part of life in Smalltalk, and can be very handy, as it
makes basically everything extensible, and lets extend things in ways
not anticipated by the author of the package you're using. For fun:

    require 'test/unit/testsuite'
    require 'test/unit/testcase'
    require 'test/unit/ui/console/testrunner'

    class ArrayOfTests < Array
	def run(result)
	    each { |test| test.run(result) { } }
	end
    end

    class SampleTestCase < Test::Unit::TestCase
	def test_nil_is_nil
	    assert_nil(nil)
	end
    end

    suite = Test::Unit::TestSuite.new
    arrayOfTests = ArrayOfTests.new
    suite << arrayOfTests

    2.times { arrayOfTests << SampleTestCase.new("test_nil_is_nil") }

    Test::Unit::UI::Console::TestRunner.run(suite)

One can even keep the "dynamic" feel of this but still have static
typing by having the compiler do type inference, as done in Haskell and
ML.
